claim: No machine has been shown to rigorously detect all kinds of lies when it comes to determining if someone is lying.

supporting.text: Current lie detection technologies, such as polygraphs, rely on physiological responses that can be manipulated or misinterpreted, making them unreliable for all types of lies.

attacks.text: Current lie detection technologies, such as polygraphs, rely on physiological responses that can be manipulated or misinterpreted, making them unreliable for all types of lies.
Some advanced AI-based lie detection systems analyze micro-expressions and speech patterns, which are harder to consciously control than physiological responses.
Even AI systems analyzing micro-expressions can be fooled by trained individuals or actors who can control their facial expressions and speech patterns.
Polygraphs have been shown to be reliable in controlled settings where baseline measurements are properly established.
Controlled settings are not representative of real-world scenarios where variables cannot be perfectly accounted for.
Functional MRI (fMRI) has shown promise in detecting lies by measuring brain activity, which is not easily consciously controlled.
fMRI is expensive, impractical for widespread use, and still produces false positives and negatives in lie detection.

supporting.text: Psychological studies show that human deception is highly context-dependent, and no machine has been developed to account for all possible contextual variables.

attacks.text: Psychological studies show that human deception is highly context-dependent, and no machine has been developed to account for all possible contextual variables.
Recent advances in AI, such as transformer models, have demonstrated the ability to process and interpret complex contextual information in natural language.
While AI models can process context, they still lack the nuanced understanding of human emotions and social cues that are critical for detecting deception.
Some specialized lie detection systems, like those using thermal imaging or micro-expression analysis, claim high accuracy in controlled environments.
Controlled environments do not reflect real-world complexity, and these systems often fail when tested in less predictable scenarios.

supporting.text: Even advanced AI systems trained on large datasets struggle with detecting lies in real-time due to the complexity of human behavior and the lack of universal deception indicators.

attacks.text: Even advanced AI systems trained on large datasets struggle with detecting lies in real-time due to the complexity of human behavior and the lack of universal deception indicators.
Some AI systems, like those using neuro-linguistic programming (NLP) and micro-expression analysis, have shown high accuracy in controlled lab environments.
Lab environments lack real-world noise and variability, making such systems unreliable in practical settings.
Hybrid systems combining AI with human oversight have demonstrated improved lie-detection capabilities.
Human oversight introduces subjectivity and bias, undermining the rigor of purely algorithmic detection.
Certain industries (e.g., security screenings) already deploy AI lie-detection tools with measurable success.
Success metrics in niche applications don't generalize to 'all kinds of lies,' as claimed.

supporting.text: Lie detection machines often fail to distinguish between stress caused by lying and stress caused by other factors, leading to false positives and negatives.

attacks.text: Lie detection machines often fail to distinguish between stress caused by lying and stress caused by other factors, leading to false positives and negatives.
Advanced AI-based lie detection systems can now analyze micro-expressions and voice modulation patterns, reducing reliance on stress indicators alone.
Even AI systems analyzing micro-expressions can be fooled by trained individuals or those with certain neurological conditions.
Polygraph tests have shown high accuracy rates in controlled laboratory settings when administered by trained professionals.
Laboratory settings don't reflect real-world conditions where many variables affect stress levels and behavior.
Some newer technologies like fMRI scans can detect lying with over 90% accuracy by measuring brain activity directly.
fMRI machines are prohibitively expensive and impractical for widespread lie detection use, limiting their real-world applicability.

supporting.text: No peer-reviewed study has demonstrated a machine capable of detecting all forms of deception, including lies of omission, exaggeration, and white lies, with perfect accuracy.

attacks.text: No peer-reviewed study has demonstrated a machine capable of detecting all forms of deception, including lies of omission, exaggeration, and white lies, with perfect accuracy.
Some studies have shown high accuracy in detecting specific types of lies, such as those involving facial microexpressions or physiological responses.
These high-accuracy studies are limited to controlled laboratory settings and do not generalize to real-world scenarios with diverse forms of deception.
Machine learning models are continuously improving and may eventually achieve near-perfect lie detection across all forms of deception.
Theoretical limitations, such as the inability to access ground truth in real-world scenarios, may prevent machines from ever achieving perfect lie detection.

supporting.text: The variability in human communication styles and cultural differences in expression makes it impossible for a single machine to universally detect lies across all populations.

attacks.text: The variability in human communication styles and cultural differences in expression makes it impossible for a single machine to universally detect lies across all populations.
Machine learning models can be trained on diverse datasets that include a wide range of communication styles and cultural expressions, potentially overcoming these limitations.
Even with diverse datasets, subtle nuances in communication may still be missed, especially in cultures or contexts not well-represented in the training data.
Advances in AI, such as transfer learning, allow models to adapt to new communication styles and cultural expressions with minimal additional training.
Transfer learning still requires some initial data from the new context, which may not always be available or sufficient for accurate lie detection.
